COLLECTION OF STATUTES

CONNECTED WITH THE

General Administration of the Law;

ARRANGED ACCORDING TO THE ORDER OF SUBJECTS:

WITH NOTES,

By Sir WILLIAM DAVID EVANS, Knt.

LATE RECORDER OF BOMBAY.

The Third Edition, corrected;

COLLATED WITH THE ORIGINAL STATUTES,

AND BROUGHT DOWN TO 10 GEO. IV.

By ANTHONY HAMMOND, Esq.

OF THE INNER TEMPLE;

AND CONTINUED FROM THAT PERIOD TO THE 5 & 6 WILL. IV. INCLUSIVE.

By THOMAS COLPITTS GRANGER, Esq.

OF THE INNER TEMPLE, BARRISTER AT LAW.

IN TEN VOLUMES.

VOL. VIII.

LONDON:

THOMAS BLENKARN, 19, CHANCERY LANE; EDWARD LUMLEY, 56, CHANCERY LANE; AND W.H. BOND, 8, BELL YARD, TEMPLE BAR.

1 in the beneficial occupation of a subject, whether he be a civil or a military officer, is equally rateable. II. Of the subject matter rated.

§[7] If a parson lease the entire tithes to one person, the lessee is liable; but the parson or lessee, agreeing with the particular tenants for the reten-tion of their tithes, is rateable as occupier; 8 Mod. 61; Lambeth, 1 Str.526.

Hie parsen is rateable for the tithe of fish caught and brought on shore; Carlyon, 3 T. R. 383. Oblations and offerings are rateable; Diet. ibid.

A certain payment, established by act of parliament in lieu of tithes, is rateable; Lowndes v. Horne, 2 Black. 1252; Hume c. Pickering, Cald. 196; unless there is a particular .ground in the Act for inferring the contrary, as in Rexc. Toms, Doug. 401. — [In that case, an option was given to the parish to pay a certain sum in lieu of the specific payments, which were expressly exempted from parochial taxes.]

4 [8] In the case of the Governor and Company for Smelting Lead e. Richardson, 3 Bur. 1311, it was ruled, that lead mines were not rateable; the Court inferring (with what degree of reason it is not material to examine), that the expression of coal mines in the statute of Elisabeth, excludes mines of any other sort as mucli as if they had been excepted.

The case has been followed as an authority ever since, and accordingly a rate on " iron and coal mines" was quashed; Cunningham, 5 Hast, 478.

But a duty of lot and cope, payable to the lord or lessee of the crowo, from mines, in proportion to their produce, is rateable; Howler v. Gill, Cowp. 451. [Qu. under what coords of the Act.] So Toll Tin, St. Agnes, 3 T. R. 480.

So the lessees(running no risque, nor incurring any expense) under the lord of a manor, of the "lot, toll, and free share, " of calamine mines; Baptist Milt Company, 1 M. and . 612.

Coal mines are rateable, although the tessee does not receive so much as the rent and expenses; Parrott, 5 T. R. 593.

[Per Lord Kenyon.—" The objection of the appellants Is, that they have made an unprofitable bargain with the lessees; hut we cannot examine into that, it being sufficient to make them liable, that they are occupiers of rateable property."—This is evidently a general principle, and not confined to the particular subject.]

But the mine being exhausted, no rate is payable for an annual rent iu respect of it, to be paid whether coal should be gotten or not; Bedworth, fl T. K. 387.

Neither can a rate be made in respect of a demise of mines, subject to certain reservations on the minerals got, the mines not being, in fact, worked; 1 Bishop of Rochester and others, 12 East, 353.

Lime works are rateable, and not exempted as mines; Alberbury, 1 E.

OF RELIEF AGAINST POOR RATES BY APPEAL OR AC

$ [14] If a person, not having rateable property within the pari* trained upon for a poor rate, it seems clear that he has a remedy I of trespass; a great many of the cases respecting rateability havi upon such actions.

In other cases the remedy must be by appeal.

The sessions are exclusively the judges of the quantum or value oi property; and it is for them to decide whether lands and buildingi rated in the same or different proportions; Brograve, 4 Cur. *491 Caldcc. 93; Sandwich, Caldcc. 103.

But if the sessions state a principle of rating which is contrary t< not rating improvements), the Court of B. R. may give relief; Mast. 61

The rate should be at the present improved value, without regu rent; . C. and Shingle, 7T.R. 549.

A third person cannot appeal on the ground of one person bsi rather than another, for other property (the property itself being full] Semble, Rex r. Brown, 8 E. 5*8.

Upon an appeal, the respondents mnst support the rate, both as tc and amount; Topham, 12 E. 546.

Formerly, if a rate was objected to on account of any person being or under-rated, it could not be amended; and, if objectionable, nfl been quashed. But the law, in this respect, is altered by stat 41 C C. 23.

With respect to the sessions to which the appeal must be made, proper notice of appeal, see 17 Geo. II. c. 38; 41 Geo. III. c. 23.

no) A rate could not be made under this Act to reimburse overseers; Tawney’s Case, 2 Salk. 531; nor by an overseer for sfl years, to reimburse himself the expenses of a preceding year; Go< 6 T. K. 149.

But see statute 41 Geo. III. c. 23. s.9, post.

A rate cannot be made for repayment of money, borrowed to n repair a workhouse; Wevill, Doug. 111.

As to power of purchasing houses, see 9 Geo. I. c. 7.

For contribution to county rates, 18 Geo. III. c. 19.

OF SETTLEMENTS AND REMOVALS.

The law of settlements is perhaps one of the strongest instances which can he cited of numerous ramifications and distinctions, of which a very few apparently plain and simple propositions may be susceptible. A foil and enlarged view of this subject is taken in several respectable publications, sufficiently familiar to the profession; but I conceive the most useful and satisfactory is that which is contained in Burn, to the later editions of which, however, it may reasonably be stated as an objection, that they retain at full length a great number of cases, some of which establish upon discussion points which may now be regarded as first principles of the subject, and others of which have long been overruled, and are become completely obsolete.

In the compressed view of the subject which is consistent with the compass of a note, I shall take for granted, without any citation of authorities, those leading rules and principles which are so familiar, that no person in the course of practice' would think it necessary to adduce any authority in support of them; referring only by name to those cases which may require a more particular attention. This is the more admissible, as the authorities, through the medium of the publications above alluded to, are of such perfect facility of access; and in order to promote that facility still further, I shall adopt the arrangement of the last edition of the work already mentioned.

It should always be remembered as a preliminary consideration, that the system is primarily founded upon the modifications of the original and subsisting statute of the 43d. EUz. c. 2. (ante No. 1.) which provides •relief for the persons therein enumerated, and .who may be designated generally as the poor.

Under this statute relief was to be applied to persons who were the objects of it, by the parish in which they might happen to be; but, for the reasons stated in the statute 13 & 14 Ch. II. c. 12., it was enacted, that within forty days after any poor person coming to settle in any tenement under 101. a-year, they might be removed to the place where they were last legally settled, for the space of forty days at the least, either as a native householder, sojourner, apprentice, or servant.

The term of forty days was, by subsequent statutes of 1 Jac. II. c. 17. s.3. 3 and 4 W. and M. c. 11. restrained to cases of a notice being given in writing, and published in the church, subject to certain qualifications contained in the latter statute, which should render such notice unnecessary, and which, being accompanied with the primary quality of a residence of forty days prescribed by the statute of Charles, should be considered as equivalent. To the several Acts and qualifications so introduced, together with the circumstance mentioned in the statute of Charles, of occupying a tenement of the yearly value of 101. the courts of law applied the term gaining a settlement, ana have superadded by analogy, real or supposed, other cases, to which a similar effect should be given.

41

bss XXVIII.] Poor.

he expression jnst referred to, of gaining a settlement, is a striking illusion of the power of language over opinions; for although nothing ir pe obvious to the slightest attention, than that the advantage of a settle-it in one parish or another, must, as regards the object of it, depend upon-lateral and accidental circumstances, the change of settlement was regard-is an advantage, and a reward for some meritorious conduct; and in ctfn-•eoce of that impression, every ingenuity has been exercised to construe [statutes in such a manner as that parties should not be deprived of the rite which they had such an interest to acquire; and although the fallacy hr opinion is now pretty generally admitted, the effect of it upo*i the sys-Isflaw still continues to operate, and very rightly so, in supporting a conation, the original justice and propriety of which, in mgpy instances, was test extremely dubous. In all cases where no parish can be found to-ich a removal can be made under the authority of the statute of Charles,

: original obligation upon the parish where the party may happen to be, continues.

emerits are either original or derivative; the first arising either by ior the several qualifications introduced by statute, to which the courts r have added the ownership of an estate; the second consisting of the ment which a wife derives from the husband, by which her own presettlement is destroyed, and that which children derive from their its, until they have acquired a settlement of their own. la all the cases included in the first division, except that of birth, the pri-pj qualification of the statute of Charles, a residence of forty days is in-pjaably requisite; and the effect of this qualification upon the settle-met, when there has been a variety or succession of residences, depends m the place of passing the last night during the continuance of the meter or relation from which the settlement is derived, accompanied a preceding residence to the amount of thirty-nine nights in the whole, 1 without any teference to the interval which may have elapsed between i last night and any of the preceding ones; but in the case of a servant, party must have passed these forty nights in the compass of a year; 4am, 1 M. and . Ml: see post, title Apprenticeship, as to what shall be Red the last night.

he language of most of the cases is, that the settlement is where the Itj sleeps the last night, but in the case of Ringwood, 1 M. and . 381., was held that the rule was satisfied by passing the last night in packing goods, without going to bed, and that what will satisfy pernoctavit is kient.

Previous to the statute of 35 Geo. III. c. 101., a poor person was liable be removed, as being likely to be chargeable. As might therefore natu-b be expected, no cases occiit of settlement by notice in writing, as such lice would immediately, wherever it was practicable, have been followed a removal: but this statute having confined the power of removal to the k of persons actually chargeable, it likewise abolished the settlement by

t, which would have enabled any person to choose a settlement at his

Certain restrictions upon the power of removal, and also of th$ power of raining a settlement, were introduced in the case of certificates, which the ht-mentioned statute has rendered comparatively unimportant, but which [il be duly noticed.

Section I.—Settlement by Birth.

Settlement by birth is divided into the two cases of bastards^ and legitime children; in each case birth is a fact which must be proved in the same aner as any other, by positive or circumstantial evidence:reputation or Rasay is not admissible evidence upon the subject; Erith, 8 East, 539.

A legitimate child, if neither the father or mother have a settlement which is known, is settled at the place of birth.

It is said, Dalt. 168, Comb. 364, 372, that a child must be sent to where it was first knotfn to be, if no other settlement is known; but this seems very doubtful, and I have never known it acted upon.

Section II.—Settlement by Parentage.

A legitimate child follows the settlement of its father, or if none such is known, that of its mother, and continues to follow the change of such settlement, except in the case of the mother acquiring a new settlement by a second marriage, until emancipation.

Emancipation is the term (borrowed with some impropriety from the civil law) applied to children who no longer follow the settlement of their parents. The cases of it, as enumerated by Lord Kenyou, have always been decided on the circumstances, either

1. Of the son’s being 21; or

2. Married; or

3. Having gained a settlement in his own right; or

4. Having contracted a relation inconsistent with the idea of being

in a subordinate situation in his father’s family.

1. The mere attaining 21 is not an emancipation; but if after the age of pupilage a child sever himself from his father’s family, |ie cannot a tier wards be incorporated with it. In the principal cases the pauper was emancipated by going out for eight weeks as a wet-nurse; Roach, 6 T. R. 247. A daughter who, at the age of eleven, went with her father’s consent to live with a relation, and continued with him until after twenty-one, was held to be thereby emancipated; Cowhoneyburnc, 10 E. 88.

2. Marriage is universally an emancipation, notwithstanding a continued residence with the parents; Everton, 1 East, 526.

3. In the case of a person under age, there is no emancipation by an apprenticeship under a void indenture, a hiring and service for a year to a certificated person, or other act of a similar nature, unless a settlement is actually gained; Edgeworth, 3 T. R. 254; Wilton, 3 T. R. 355; Coljingburu Duels, 4T. R. 199.

4. Inlisting as a soldier: but Q. in case the party returns when under age; which case does not appear ever to have been decided: and see the case of Roach, supra 1.

Conformably with the above principles, a child is not emancipated by

1. Following business on his own account; continuing to live with his mother; Sowerby, 2 East, 276.

2. Serving in the militia; Woburn, 8 T. R. 479.

kss XXVIII.] Poor. 4S

t Working about the country on his own account; Halifax v. Warley,

. C. 806.

k Residing under age with a relation or other person; Tottington Lower P, Cald. 284; Offchurch, 3 T. R. 114.

I. The services are sufficiently connected, t. Although there is a difference of wages, as where the first wages are by tfceweek and the second by the year.

Cases of express dissolution and dispensation.

I. There is an implied dispensation,

1. Where the servant absents himself, and is afterwards received ngaj which is called purging the absence.

2. Where the servant does not come until after the time appointed, ai is received.

3. If the servant runs away, and; after several weeks, is apprehend* under a warrant, and received back with an abatement of wages; Ea Sheffield, 4 T. R. 804.

II. There is not such dispensation.

If the servant, before the commencement of the service, is taken ill, th master refuses to receive him as incapable, and the servant agrees to Uk such wages as lie will allow; Wintersett, Cald. 298.

An absence by reason of illness does not prevent the settlement, altliong the servant does not return, and is incapable of returning, to his master, a where he became a lunatic, and was taken to his father's; Sutton, 5T. R 657.

[Per Lord Kenyon—The settlement is where he was last in th service; but this point does not arise in the case, and the otbe judges gave no opinion on it.—Ruled to be so in case of apprentice ship; Barm by in the Marsh, 7 E. 383.

A dismissal for a reasonable cause, as of a female servant for being witl child, is a dissolution of the contract, and defeats the settlement; Ashovei

e. Brampton, Cald. 11.

But there is no dissolution,

1. If the master before the end of the year tnrns the servant out of doors, to prevent his gaining a settlement; Eastland v, Westhorsley, 1 Str. 526.

2. Where the master refused to allow the servant to return, after an absence for a reasonable cause; Gresham, 1 T.R. 101.

3. When the master, a short time before the end of the year, for an insuffi' cient cause turned away the servant, who was willing to stay, and returned the next day for her clothes-, and received the wages offered to her as the full amount of what she was entitled to as a year’s wages, but leas than she demanded, (there being a dispute as to the amount) and offered to stay to the end of the year; Hardhorn with Newton, 12 E. 51.

Cases of Dissolution and Dispensation by express Agreement.

These are very numerous and seemingly very irreconcileable.—In the case of Thistleton, 6 T. R. 185, Lord Kenyon laid down the principle as follows:—" If the pauper be absent from the service with the concurrence, remaining, however, subject to the controu! of his master, he may acquire a settlement, because this only amount! to a dispensation with his service; but if the master has once parted with his controul over the servant, there no settlement is gamed, and the receiving the whole year’s wages does not make any difference."

The application of this plain and distinct principle will certainly overturn many of the cases, in which it has been held that there was only a dispensation.

In some of the later cases, however, cited infrd, and which have been decided since the preparing this note, the Court of B. R. has given full effect to the application of the principle, in opposition to the finding of the sessions. —See particularly Rex v. Bury, infri. II. 11.

Section V.—Op Apprenticeship.

To constitute a contract of apprenticeship there must necessarily be deed, and according to stat. 5 Elizabeth, it should be an indenture; but X 31 Geo. II. c. 11. the being indented is unnecessary so far as regards tl question of settlement.

By statutes 8 Anne, c. 9. and 9 Anne, c. 21. a duty of 6d. in the pound fi 501. or under, and of 12d. for every pound above, of money, or other thin| not money, according to their value, is imposed on indentures of appro ticeship, except money given with parish apprentices, or by or out of puM charities.

Many cases arose upon the point, whether the duty was payable in cas of a covenant by the father or other relation to maintain the apprentice which were decided upon their particular circumstances, and the genen

auestion was as much as possible avoided, until the case of Leighton, 41 :. 732, in which it was decided that no such duty is payable; the op non of the court being, upon a full consideration of the subject, that the ol ligation of providing tor apprentices did not result from the mere relation < master and apprentice.

An agreement by the apprentice to allow two shillings a 'week out i wages to be paid by the master, does not require, a stamp; Bradford, l Jty and . 151.

V great subject of litigation in modern cases has been the principle, that f extract intended as an apprenticeship, and imperfect as such, shall not fare as a service.

This first occurred in Salford t>. Storeford, 2 Bott. 363, where the instruct which purported to be an indenture of apprenticeship was not stamped:ti several other cases of a similar nature occurred previous to the case or ttle Bolton, Cald. 367, in which the pauper asked the master to teach him weave; the master agreed to do so if he would work with him three vs, the earnings to be divided between them, and an agreement in wri-gwas entered into accordingly. The court first thought that this was an prentfceship, as the pauper was to be taught; but afterwards Lord nriield said, upon looking into the authorities, that all those cases of prenticeship which had been holden to be defective, and were not con-itible into services, spoke of the pauper as an apprentice, and that he u to serve as such.

la the case of Highnam, 2 Bott. 371, which immediately followed, the per went for the purpose of being an apprentice, and paid four guineas; t, to save the expense of the indenture and duty, they agreed to sign an agree-ent on unstamped paper: it was held to be clear that a fraud was intended, d therefore that no settlement was gained by service.

Subsequent to this, a pauper agreed to serve seven years as on apprentice, m so agreement was signed, and it was held not to be a service; Margram, L 193.

Ike pauper clubbed with the master, which was to be taught a trade, to Rrv« three years at progressive wages; he was to do any work the master set fa shout; and this was ruled to be a service. Lord Kenyon thought the l fact decisive; Coltishall, 5 T. R. 195.

Thus stood the authorities upon the subject previous to the case of Lain *, fa, 8 T. R. 379; and it seemed to be considered as a settled point, than an freement to serve on the one band and to instruct on the other was to be Igarded as a valid service, and not as an imperfect apprenticeship, unless e express agreement was that the party should serve as an apprentice, or less there was an actual intention of defrauding the revenue by the eva- of the stamp duty.

11st in the case of Laindon, there being a written agreement that the faper should serve for three years, to learn a trade at certain wages, with ifnof by parol that at the time of signing the agreement the pauper agreed I give three guineas as a premium, which sum was partly paid, and partly, fared in the amount of wages, and that be was not to be employed in any far work than that of a carpenter; the contract was held to be invalid as I imperfect apprenticeship.—The following is the material part of Lord knyon’s judgment upon the subject.

J. Lawrence, after expressing his opinion to the same effect, observed, I " it was much to be lamented that settlement cases should be determined nice distinctions; it would be better to decide them on some general n that every person who reads can understand it."

In the subsequent case of Rainham, 1 E. 531, an agreement by deed forparty to teach and the other to learn, with certain wages, was held to giv settlement by apprenticeship: but the question between service and appr ticeship in that case did not precisely occur, for there was a service of m than a year; therefore, quacunque via, $c., if the service had been less tl a year, the distinction would have been material.

This case was soon followed up by that of Eccleston, 2 E. 230, in wh the contract was in the precise terms of the case of Little Bolton, and settlement was held to be gained by service; Lord Ellenborough declai that he gave a reluctant assent to the case of Little Bolton, but as the c was in terms the same, he thought it better to abide by that determinal than to introduce uncertainty into that branch of the law; it being oftei more importance to have the rule settled than to determine what it sho be. He was not, however, convinced by the reasoning of that case, am the point were new he should think otherwise. Upon the whole view of this subject, which, in the course of my observain of the practice of the quarter-sessions, has produced more litigation than Wj other, (although the cow tenements are bidding fair to rival it), it may, llconceive, be now fairly inferred, that a contract for the one party to Me, and for the other to teach a trade, is a contract of service, and not a Ihetive apprenticeship, unless (after all the railing at the King and Little torn) the term apprentice is actually mentioned in the contract; or unless pramum* is given for the instruction; in which cases the contract is void, ifess invested with all the requisites of a valid apprenticeship.

[The maxim that there is no magic in words, which is often pronounced with such imposing solemnity, has always appeared to xnc to have more sound than meaning.

I apprehend that there is no word which has so absolute and technical a sense that it may not be qualified and controuled by the context and the nature of the subject to which it is applied: although there are many cases in the law, in which certain technical words arc essentially necessary to produce a certain legal effect, and many others in which the usual import affixed to a particular expression can only be controuled by matter of absolute and necessary inference to the contrary; and whoever has contemplated with general views our cumbrous mass of cases upon the construction of wills, must be satisfied of the advantage to the community in lessening litigation, and giving certainty to titles by adhering to known and precise rules of construction, in preference to wandering into the regions of conjecture in search of an intention as deduced from expressions, which the party who used them in all probability never dreamed of, as indicating the intention inferred from them; especially as the system adopted is neither purely technical, nor purely matter of construction upon the actual intention, but a kind of unmeaning and unsettled compound of the two. In matters of a positive nature, in which, upon principle, the preference of one course or another is a "priori indifferent, the great criterion of excellence is clearness and certainty, and therefore in cases of this description, the more technical the course which is adopted, the more beneficial are in general the consequences. It is otherwise in matters when there is a principle of propriety arising out of the nature of the subject, in which the accidental forms of language should rather he considered as subordinate to the intention and purposes of the parties; particularly in the case of contracts, and in which a refusal to deviate from the strict and dictionary sense of the tenus, in opposition to the unambiguous intention, is a violation of the superior principles of justice.

This has always most forcibly appeared to me to be the case with respect to the decision in Jones v. Brierly, 1 £. 1. in which it was held that an agreement to pay a per centage upon any Money which the defendant should receive, though the plaintiffs informa£

The statute 9 Anne, c. 9. imposes the duty on all sums paid in relation to any clerk, apprentice or servant a, to learn any profession, trade or employment.

Poor. [Part VI.

tion did not extend to the transfer of stock (stock not being money) z for no fair and reasonable doubt conld be entertained that In this contract the term Motf ey was used as importing property. The court animadverted upon the immorality of the bargain in question, and probably gave a construction different from that which they would have done if the contract had been of a more favourable nature: but that objection should have'gone for every thing or for nothing, and the case, though founded upon that decision, which, next to a mere opinion at Nisi Prius, is or all others the least satisfactory, the refusal upon sudden impulse to grant a rule to shew canse will hereafter stand recorded as a precedent in the way of any claim, however meritorious, resting upon a similarity of circumstances in point of expression. In the famous case of Haycraft r. Creasy, 2 £.92. the defendant, who was charged with giving E. H. a false character, said he knew she was a lady of fortune: that he said so under a full impression that she was so, from facts which he regarded as conveying absolute knowledge, and by which he wan himself deluded—was an adiqitted fact in the case: but Lord Kenyon, from the mere literal application of the word knew, would have fixed upon him the character of frand; and it is well known that he felt great dissatisfaction with the other judges, who, fortunately for the true principles of justice, were of a different opinion.

In the case of Shinfield, (the last case in the text to which this note is attached:I am quite aware with bow much digression) Mr. Justice Le Blanc adverts to the true ground upon which the class of cases under discussion originated; but from which, in the progress of the taw, there has been a considerable deviation; and has shewn that it was merely a question of revenue, and arising from an intention to avoid the stamp laws.

At common law, a contract that one party shall serve another, who shall in retorn instruct him in the business, in which the service is to be performed, (which instruction is commonly the mere effect and consequence of the service) is in its nature as open and unexceptionable as any other of the numerous contracts which parties may enter into, with a view of mutual convenience. To such a contract, when invested with certain solemnities, the law has given the appellation of apprenticeship, attaching to the relation which is so contracted certain legal consequences; but because, in respect of the derivation of the term, it may be inferred that every contract of apprenticeship is a contract of service and instruction, it does not follow that every contract of service and instruction is an apprenticeship, so as to be void as a general contract at common law, unless invested with those special qualities which are attached by the law to the contract, technically denoted by that term; or that the incorrect insertion and admixture of such a term should vitiate the obligation that would otherwise have been effectually contracted between the parties. Nor can I conceive that if before the subject had received any prejudice from the decision upon cases of settlement, the question had arisen upon a case between the parties to the contract, the obligation which would otherwise have attached would by such an admixture have been defeated. In the law of real property, nothing Is more familiar than that an instrument which cannot operate in the precise manner which its form and expressions would import, shall operate in such other manner as will, consistently with the rules of law, effectuate the intention of the parties; as in the case of a feoffment without livery operating as a bargain and sale, or a covenant to stand seised.

In Salford v. Storeford, the first and leading case upon the subject under discussion, the instrument had all the requisites of a deed except a stamp; and without any particular reference to the settlement law, there is no dotibt that, as a general proposition, a deed which is defective for want of a stamp cannot be set up as an agreement. In the second case of Whitchurch r. Wotton Fitzpayne, B. . C. 540, it was agreed that the party should be an apprentice, and that indentures of apprenticeship should be executed, so that the parties never had it in contemplation that

5:

Ckss XXVIII.] Poor.

any relation should be contracted between them except that of a strict apprenticeship, which is very different from the cases where a complete and executed agreement was intended to be contracted, although expressed by an improper designation; but it is certain that the law has in subsequent cases, upon the mere supposed authority of these decisions, been carried, and is now established much further than the authority of the cases would necessarily require, or even fairly justify.]

There must be a service under the indenture for forty days, in the place where the settlement is claimed, and the settlement is where the party slept the last night, having been there forty days in the whole.

An apprentice leaving his master’s house to sleep at his mother’s, in a different parish, for the purpose of being cured of a disorder, continuing to be oqdoyed by his master, is settled in the parish where he sleeps; Stratford-pon-Avon, 11 E. 176.

But sleeping in a different parish where the apprentice is taken on account of illness, (doing no service for his master) is not a residence by which any settlement can be gained; Barmby in the Marsh, 7'E. 583; Scholefield, B.

. C. 511.

Where a master to whom an apprentice was assigned told the apprentice, a short time before the expiration of the term, that he must go and work elsewhere; and the apprentice slept a night in the parish where his first aster lived, bat did not see or apply to him, and had not any intention of doing so; it was held that that night could not be coupled with the former residence, so as to give a settlement; Smarsden, 13 E. 452.

If there be a service with a different person by assignment from the first aster, it is sufficient: so an assignment from a second to a third, Ac. c.

A service with another person by the consent of the master, or the person ts whom the apprentice is assigned, is sufficient; but it must be actual and express consent to the particular service; mere knowledge of the particular service, or mere general consent to serve with any person, or the union of the two, is not sufficient. Since Statute 32 Geo. III. c. 37, ante. Title Apprentices, No. 10, a settlement is not gained by a parish apprentice, who, by the consent of his mistress, during her life-time, lived with her son, and after her death with another person, by the son’s consent; Sheepshead, 15 E. 59.

[I should have very much doubted whether this Act could properly affect a question of settlement, as the obligation of master and apprentice, at common law, wholly ceased by the death of the master; and the regulations of the Act have no direct reference to the question of settlements, with regard to which this relation was in preceding cases held to continue.]

While the indenture continues in force, no settlement can be gained with a third person by hiring or service.

If the apprentice is bound by his father, the apprenticeship cannot, while he is an infant, be put an end to by agreement between the master and apprentice, without the assent of his lather, neither can a parish apprentice without the consent of the overseers; but an apprentice when of age, may, by agreement with the master, put an end to the apprenticeship without any consent.

If the master is dead, the apprentice is at liberty to hire himself without any consent from the master’s representatives.

The bankruptcy of the master does not determine the apprenticeship.

In what cases the apprenticeship is dissolved.

1. An exchange or delivering up of the indentures without cancellation.

2. A sum of money was paid by the father to the master, who gave a receipt for it, as from the apprentice for the remainder of his time, and offered to give up the indentures, which the father did not take, not thinking it material; Harberton, 1 T. R. 139.

In what not,

1. P. agreed verbally with M. to give him----for the remainder of his

time: it was agreed that M. should keep the indentures till the money was to be paid, which was to be from time to time, as P. could earn it; Slieh-beaxe, 1 E. 73.

[The decision in this case was, that a settlement was gained by apprenticeship; there being a consent to the service with C., with whom P. was hired.]

2. By the apprentice entering as a sailor in the navy; Hindringham, 6 T. R. 557.

[This case turned on the power of an apprentice to vacate the contract; as to which see Notes on Stat. 5 Eliz. ante. Title Apprenticeship, No. 1.]

3. Agreement that P. should work for his own benefit, paying M.---per week; Offerton v. Stockport, B. . C. 802.

[Settlement by apprenticeship under circumstances of consent.]

The proof of indentures of apprenticeship, in cases of settlement, depends upon the same rule as the proof of deeds and instruments in other cases.

If lost, and all reasonable inquiry is made for the indentures from the person in whose hands they ought to be, and where they were last proved to be, secondary evidence wiil be received.

An indenture produced by the adverse party, upon notice, does not prova itself, and must be regularly proved by subscribing witnesses; Gordon v, Secretan, 8 E. 548; over-niUng Middezoy, 2 T. R. 41.

An indendure upon which a premium was paid having been lost, and the pauper having been relieved by the parish for several years (residing there), the sessions presumed the duty to have been paid, although proved by th^ officer of stamps not to have been inrolled. Lord Ellen borough—" The question before the sessions was, whether the presumption that all was rightly done, after the lapse of so many years, were sufficiently rebutted by the negative evidence of the officer:they thought not; and we cannot say

Class XXVIII.] Poor.

that they have done wrong, for the presumption of the law is to be favoured; and against the negative evidence they may have set the possibility of an irregularity in the return made to the officer Long Buckley, 7 E. 45.

[This can only shew, that if the sessions inferred the faot from the length of time, their inference could not be set aside as founded upon premises not adequate in point 6f law. It certainly did not prescribe any rule to sessions, that in similar cases they ought to make such presumption; and the true application of the rule, that omn>a presumuntur rite atse acla, would be rather in favour of the supposition, that if the duty had been paid the indenture would have been inrolted. To call the regular official document, in which, according to law and practice, the duty, if paid, would have been entered, negative evidence, seems to be rather a perversion of the term. Negative evidence is that which is consistent with the thing supposed to be negatived, having been done, but not observed or attended to:this is positive evidence of an existing state of things, contrary to that which would have existed if the requisites of the law hail been properly complied with.]

Section VI.—Of Settlement by taking a Tenement of 101.

A-YEAR.

I. What tenements have been held to give a settlement.

1. Coney Warren and Cottage; Kinver v. Stone, 2 Sir. 618.

2. A Rabbit Warren, without any other right in the soil than that of entering upon and killing rabbits there; Piddletrenthide, 3 T. R. 772.

3. A Fishery; Old Alresford v. Chilton Candover, 1 T. R. 358.

4. A Cattle gate: Whixley, 1 T. R. 137.

5. A right of common in gross; Dersingham, 7 T. R. 671.

6. The toll of a fair or market; Chipping Norton, 5 E. 239. But not upon a parol demise, being a mere licence; ruled ibid.

[But how could this be distinguished from the preceding case of the common, both being incorporeal hereditaments, which could not pass without deed ? The same observation will apply to the case of the rabbit warren, and all the subsequent cases respecting the pasture of cows, &c., these being mere incorporeal rights, passing not the soil itself, but merely an incidental right, lying only in grant, and in respect to which, if a title were to be set out in pleading, a mere parol contract would not be sufficient.]

7. Tolls of a bridge, though declared to be personal estate; Bub with, 1 M. and . 514.

8. A water-mill or wind-mill.

9. After-grass; Brampton, 4 T. R. 348.

10. The pasturage of a cow.

[In the first case upon this subject (Lockerley, B. . C. 315) it was held that a covenant to demise a house, with sixteen cows, and pasture on twenty-one acres, was not a tenement, but a mere personal contract; but in the cases of Piddletrenthide, 3 T. R. 772; Tolpuddlc, 4 T. R. 671, it was fully settled, that the letting of cows to be depastured in particular lands constituted a tenement in respect of the lands: and Lord Kenyon laid it down generally in the latter case, that any thing is a tenement which is profit oat of land:and these cases have been followed up by others, holding that the mere pasture of a cow, &c. in a ley with others, constitutes a tenement: but the value must be complete from the pasturage, without taking into account the use of the cow; Min worth, 2 E. 198.

In Didsbury, Nol. P. L. 25, Lawrence J. said, a contract to feed generally, under which they might be fed with green tares, would not be a tenement; which, to be sure, would seem almost as evident as that a contract tQ feed a man would not be a tenement.

But in Parley Abbey, 14 E. 280, where the agreement was for the milk of a cow for the season, and the person letting said at the time that A. B. would shew in what field the cow would first be milked, it was ruled by the sessions that a settlement was gained, which was confirmed in K. B. The chief point in discussion seems to have been, whether it was not properly inferred to have been the intention of the parties that the cow was to be fed on land and not on bay, &c. So far as the inference goes to establish a contract in respect of particular land, there is nothing to vary the case in principle from those that preceded it, and the justice of the particular inference is an enquiry confined to the particular case; out if if

To speak of doubting or not doubting, of clear cases or doubtful cases, may do very well in the abstract; but when the meaning of the expression is examined for the purpose of accurate reasoning, the solution will not be so very satisfactory. If it is a mere question of fact as to the doubts of an individual, it might apply to thej absence of doubt arising from want of knowledge, or of power to perceive the real difficulty, as well ms from the fulness of knowledge, which is adequate completely to resolve it; and the most ignorant byestander will in general have fewer doubts than the most enlightened judge. But if it is a question arising out of Ibe nature of the subject, surely there was no question which would more reasonably admit of the doubt, and possibly of the dissent, of those habitually and professionally conversant with the subject, than the very novel propositions involved in the opinion which has been last referred to.]

Of the value of 101. a-year.

The rent is only evidence of the value, and evidence may be received to shew that the real value is more or less, of which the sessions are the conclusive judges. But evidence of rent actually paid, without particular circumstances shewing a reason for its being more or less than the actual value, is’ generally, and very properly, regarded by the sessions as such evidence of value, as to counterbalance evidence of mere opinion to the contrary. Section VIII.—Settlement by annual Office.

If any person shall (1) execute for himself, and on his own account (2) any public and annual office or charge (3) in the said town or parish (4) during one whole year, he shall have a settlement; W. c. 11. s. 6.

I. An execution for himself and on his own account; Galton v. Milwich,

2 Salk. 536.

Constable hiring another gains a settlement; Hope Mansell, Cald. 252.

Serving as deputy hired by another does not; Winterbourn r. St. Philip, B. . C. 520; Allcannings v.Putney, B. . C. 634.

II. W hat a public and annual office.

1. A parish clerk.

2- A sexton; Liverpool, 3 T. R. 118.

3. Warden of a borough, including several parishes; St* Mary v. St. Lawrence, in Reading, 2 Bott. 156.

4. Constable of city, including several parishes; St. Maurice’s c.St. Mary Calendars, in Winchester, B. . C. 27.

5. Tithingman; Burliscombe v. Sandford Peverell, 1 Str. 444.

6. Hogringer, appointed by Leet and sworn, (an ancient office, and serviceable to the inhabitants); Whittlesea, 4 T. K. 807.

7. Bailiff or aletaster for a borough, part only of the parish; appointed at the leet and sworn; Whitechurch r. Overton, B. . C. 365.

8. Collector of.duties on births and burials appointed by Commissioners; Bisham v. Cooke, 1 Str. 411.

9. Collector of land tax; Hmiimond, 2 Bott. 157.

10. Governor of workhouse at a salary; it being found by the sessions to be a public annual office; Ihninster, 1 E. 83.

[The Court said, that the finding by the sessions that it was a public annual office precluded any further discussion; but when they described the particulars wherein the functions of the^office consisted, the finding was no more than was necessarily implied in the confirmation of the order.]

III. What not.

1. Stipendiary Cnrate; Wantage, 2 E. 65.

2. Schoolmaster of a charity school; Sheepsbead v. Netborue, 2 Str. 1225.

3. Master of a workhouse engaged at a salary, and dismissed after serving a year, on a quarter’s notice; Mersham, 7 E. 167.

IV. In the parish.

The party must reside in the parish where some of the duties are performed. Sexton gains settlement if part of chapel yard is in the parish where he lives, though there are no burials during his being in the office; Liverpool, 3 T. R. 118.

V. For a year.

1. An officer becoming chargeable within the year may be removed; Tit-tleworth c. Pnllborough, B. . C. 238.

2. Serving an office at two different times, with an interval between them, there being a custom to serve for half-a-year, is not sufficient; Cold Ashton r. Woodchester, Bott. 174.

3. Appointment at adjourned leet on the 10th. Nov., and swearing to serve a year, or until lawfully discharged; service till 1st Nov., when a new officer was appointed, held sufficient; Bow, 8 T. R. 445.

Section XI.—Op Removals and Appeals.

I. An order of removal must be founded on a- complaint from the Churchwardens and overseers of the parish, or the overseers of the township, that the persons removed have come to inhabit in such parish or township, not having gained a settlement there, and that they are actually chargeable to such parish or township.

2. An adjudication of the truth of those facts.

3. An adjudication that they are settled in the place to which the removal is made.

A person meeting with an accident in a parish where he is casually at work, is not removable as having come to inhabit there; St. James’s, in Bury St. Edmund’s, 10 E. 25. But when a pauper residing in Kilburne, and relieved there, upon applying for relief Was desired to go to Fakenham, and being referred back from one to the other, was finally removed by Fakenham; the order was sustained, Lord Ellenborough saying that it was the case of a starving vagrant in whichever of the parishes she was, and she was liable to be removed from either; Birmingham, 14 E. 251.

Previous to the statute 35 Geo. III. c. 101. it was sufficient if the parties were likely to become chargeable; but in such case it was also necessary that the complaint and adjudication should state, that they had not brought a certificate acknowledging them to be settled elsewhere; it is not necessary



Class XXVIII.] Poor.

to alledge that the paupers are settled on a tenement of less than Id. a* year; Weston Rivers v. St. Peter's, 2 Salk* 493.

The justices making the order mnst appear to be justices for the county, or other district, within which the parish, See. from which the removal is made or situate. If the direction is at the beginning of the order, and two counties are there mentioned, justices for the said county is insufficient; Moor, Critchell, 2 £. 66. To prevent this mistake, it is eligible that the direction should be printed rather at the foot than at the head of the order. It is not necessary that they should be of the division; 2 Salk. 473. Justices for the borough, or town and parish, of Andover, is sufficiently certain; Caldec. 373.

The justices ought to be together at the time of the examination and order; but the objection that they were not so, can only be taken advantage of upon appeal, and does not render the order absolutely void; Stotfold, 4 T. R. 596.

There are several cases as to the necessity of setting forth the ages of children who are removed with their father to the place of his settlement; but it is now the constant course for the complaint and adjudication to refer as well to the children as the father.

A woman marrying a foreigner, or person whose settlement is not ascertained, retains her original settlement; hut cannot, if living with her husband in a different place, be removed to such settlement against his consent.

In tioylanaswain t>. Carleton, B. . C. 813, the wife and children were removed From the residence of the husband. In the statement of the case by the sessions, it was not expressly said that he did or did not consent, and the order was set aside; from which it seems to be a necessary consequence, that in such case an express consent must be proved.

An order to remove a married woman to the place of her settlement is good; Higher Walton, B. . C. 162. It is not necessary that the absence, or (come semble) the consent of the husband should appear on the face of the order; Ironactone. Painewick, B - . C. 153.

In Rex v. Hinxworth, Cald. 42, a removal of a wife and her children was held conclusive as to the settlement of the husband. Nothing appeared on the statement of facts, as reported, to shew whether the place to which the removal was made was the maiden settlement of the wife, or the supposed settlement of the husband. Lord Mansfield said, —" The general rule of law is, that the settlement of the wife and children must depend upon that of the husband; ’tis true there are excepted cases, but unless such special circumstances are stated, we are bound to presume in favour of the general rule/’ In Rex c. Leigh, Dong. 45, the reversal of an order as to the wife was, upon the authority of the preceding case, held conclusive between the same parishes as to the husband; and a removal of a married woman, under the designation of widow, has also been held conclusive as to the settlement of her husband; Rudgeley, 8 T. R. 620.

[I have thought it eligible to bring these cases, respecting the settlements of married women, together; although some of them relate more particularly to a subsequent head. It is observable, that in none of the cases in which toe settlement of the husband has been deemed to be concluded by the removal of the wife, it has distinctly and specifically appeared, that the removal was to the maiden settlement of the wife, and that the husband had no settlement in England; but if there is no exception under such circumstances. it Follows that a parish may be burthened with the settlement of a husband, contrary to the truth of the fact, by an order, against which they could not by any possibility relieve themselves by appeal, as in the case of the husband being absent, or consenting to the removal.]

It certainly is not necessary that the order should be made on the examination of the persons removed, as the settlement may depend altogether upon other evidence. In Ware v. Starstead, Mount Filchet, 2 Salk. 488, Gould said, the practice was, to make the complaint to one justice, and he grants his warrant to bring the party before two justices.

In Rex e. Jackson, 1T. R. 653, the Court of B. R. refused to grant an information against justices, for committing a pauper who refused to answer a question respecting his settlement. Ana Ashurst and Duller expressed a strong opinion iu favour of the power of such commitment.

In the case of Spittal Fields r. Bromley, above-mentioned, it was said that two townships within one parish are the same as two parishes; yet churchwardens are overseers of the poor of the whole parish (though so divided), and have a superintendency over the whole villages and townships. This seems very donbtful, especially since 17 George II. c. 38, post.; which enacts, that in such townships the overseers alone may act in all respects as churchwardens and overseers may do in other places: and I conceive that the churchwardens of a parish divided into townships, or the overseers of a township having the same name with the parish of which it constitutes a part, arc not bound to receive an order upon the parish.

The appeal may be either by the place to which the removal is made, or by the person removed.

The appeal must be to the sessions of the county, division, or riding, where the place from which the removal is made is situate, and not elsewhere; 8 and 9 W. c. 30. s. 6.

An appeal to the sessions of a borough (by the justices of which the order is made), although acquiesced in by entering on the merits, is wholly nugatory; East Donyluud r. St. Giles’s, Chichester, B. . C. 592.

The term division seems applicable only to the county of Lincoln, which is divided into three several parts, having separate commissions of the peace like the ridings of Yorkshire.

The appeal must be to the next sessions after the removal.

Except where there is not sufficient time for the purpose.

As where the removal was on the 5th of October, and the sessions held at 60 miles’ distance on the 6th (the subsequent sessions being considered in such case the next possible sessions); East Riding of Yorkshire, Doug. 183.

Where there were two intervening days, and the distance was twenty miles; ruled that the appeal ought to have been to the first sessions.

When the sessions were the day after the removal, and continued fourteen days, an appeal at the following sessions was held sufficient; and per Curiam —" The appellant parish ought to have a reasonable time for considering, whether they will appeal or not; " Surrey, 1 M. and . 479.

When the sessions of a county arc adjourned from place to place, and the removal is after the commencement of the original sessions, an appeal to the adjourned sessions of the following quarter is in time; Justices of Sussex, 7 T. R. 107.

In London and Middlesex an appeal to the next general quarter sessions is sufficient, notwithstanding there being an intermediate general sessions; Justices of London, 15 E. 632.

By 9 Geo. c. 7. s. 8. no appeal can be proceeded upon unless reasonable notice has been given; and if reasonable time of notice has not been given, the justices are to adjourn the appeal to the next sessions.

It is imperative on the sessions to receive the appeal, although notice may not have been given, and although there may have been sufficient time for the purpose; Justices of Huntingdonshire, Cald. 233; Gloucestershire, Doug. 182; Shropshire (printed by mistake in the report Staffordshire), 7 E. 549; the case of the North Riding of Yorkshire, 3 T. R. 150. Coutril, is overruled by the subsequent case of Shropshire.

Where the appeal was properly entered, but notice was not given of it before the following sessions, according to a new rule made by the sessions, and not known to the appellant’s attorney, the sessions refused to hear the appeal, or to adjourn it further, thinking they had no power to do so. The Court of K. B. held that they ought to have adjourned it, and granted a mandamus: Lord Ellenborough said, the magistrates certainly had a discretion with respect to what was reasonable time for giving notice of appeal, but that Court had also visitatorial power over them, in the exercise of such a discretionary power; Wiltshire, 10 E. 404.

With respect to hearing the appeal, it is now settled as a general rule of 5. Of hearing law, that the respondents must begin and prove their case. The practice the appeal, upon this subject was formerly regulated by the accidental usage of each particular sessions.

I apprehend that it is clearly competent for the appellant to require proof, not only of the settlement, but of the party being chargeable.

It does not seem to be material to advert to general rules of evidence which apply to cases of settlement, as there is not any difference in the application of those rales when arising in such cases, from that which prevails upon other

his seems to be the proper place to notice the evidence of relief as 6. Evidence o prirna facie proof of settlement; with respect to which it is established, that relief, evidence of relief to a person, being within the parish, and however often such relief may have been given, is not admissible; Chadderton, 2 E. 27;

Chatham, 8 E. 498, for persons requiring relief are to be relieved in the parish where the^ are, until some other place of settlement can be found; but, evidence or relief given to a person residing in another parish or township is admissible; R. r. Wakefield, 5 E. 333; and such evidence is treated, in the late editions of Burn, as forming a distinct kind of settlement; and though only prima facie evidence of settlement, it was held in Rex v. Stanley cum Wrintliorpe, 13 E. 359, that where repeated instances of such relief had been ' given to the pauper and his family, the sessions had drawn the right concliv sion in holding it not rebutted by a certificate given to the grandfather of the pauper many years before by a different parish.

And see Rex v. Barnsley, 1 M. and . 377, in which the Court held, that relief for seven years was evidence of such preponderating weight, that the sessions ought to have drawn the conclusion that the pauper was, by some means or other, a settled inhabitant:—See Observations on this Case infra.

It is evident, however, that such evidence should be received with very considerable caution, when the real facts of the case are capable of being shewn; the relief being only evidence of acknowledgement of settlement by the overseers, whose mistakes of either fact or law are not to bind the parish to which they belong: and I should be very unwilling to lay any stress upon this acknowledgment, if it appeared to have been occasioned by tacts which are within the reach of inquiry; as in any case it is incorrect to be satisfied with the presumption of a fact which is capable of proof, being in principle at least an infringement of the rule (much more known in its expression than in its just and proper application), that the best evidence should be required which the nature of the case will admit.

The Annual Mutiny Act contains a provision, that if any non-commissioned 7. Exam inn-officer or soldier shall have a wife or children, two justices may summon him tions under tfi where he is quartered, to make oath of the place of ids settlement, and he Mutiny Act. shall obey such summons and make oath accordingly; and the justices shall give an attested copy of such affidavit to be delivered to the commanding officer, to be produced when required; which attested copy shall be at any time admitted in evidence as to such settlement, before any justices, or at any sessions; and if he be summoned again to make such oath as aforesaid, then, on such attested copy of the oath by him previously made being produced, he shall not be obliged to take any other or further oath with regard to his settlement, but shall leave a copy of such attested examination if required.

In Rex v. Clayton le Moors, 5 T. R. -704, an attested copy of an examination, but which had not been delivered to the commanding officer, was held DM admissible in evidence, not being such copy as the Act requires. Lord Kenyon observed—" Whether it was or was not wise to introduce such a clause in the Mutiny Acts, which was not formerly contained in those^ statutes, it is unnecessary to inquire; but the question here is, whether this act of Parliament, which makes an innovation on the law of evidence, should be
